utterances: And let me tell you what it's like.
Well, what do I do?
Am I going to get enough insurance to fix up where I left?
Are the flood plans going to tell me something that will say, oh, boy, you can't live here?
There are so many mixed signals.
And I think our challenge is to make it clear you can come home.
Everybody ought to have a right to come home.
I'd like to ask you about one other subject before you all go, and that's leadership.

This city is going to have elections soon, and it seems that between our system of checks and balances, federalism, home rule, lots of people have been confused by their elected officials here over the past few months.
It's been a rough time to try to take guidance from leadership.
What does this city need?
Not an individual, but what does it need in the way of leadership that it might conceivably get out of an election or two?
Well, I guess I'm the oldest sitting around here, and I've watched leadership in the city for a long time.
I think this city needs first somebody who isn't worried about whether he or she is going to get reelected.
Now, I'd vote for somebody.
You would vote for somebody.
I'd vote for somebody who said let me tell you something, you may not like me, but I'm telling you, this is what we have to do.
You know, and deep down, the city would rally around that individual.
Although, in this context ""you may not like me"" doesn't just mean I'm going to reduce garbage collection on your street.
It means I'm going to tell you not to live there anymore.
It's pretty big stakes for government.

Well, you know, if you are convinced as a leader that your not living there is the most important thing, not because you are female, not because you're black, not because you're white, but I'm doing it because you are a human being that doesn't deserve to be treated that way.
Those decisions are going to have to be made.
I'm convinced of that.
But part of the problem that we've dealt with for years is that we've neglected to realize that race and gender and color still matter.
As long as you put it aside, it keeps showing up, because you've not dealt with it.
And I think that kind of leader, who starts to deal with it, I think will galvanize the city.
I could write the details of what it would take.
And I'm not running for mayor.
I'd like to take us back, since we're talking about mayoral elections, how do you hold an election in a city where so many of the residents are scattered far and wide?
Kim Boyle?
I think that there are serious issues related to holding the election right now.
Many of our citizens who've evacuated have absolutely no idea how the absentee voting process is going to work.
And the right to vote is probably one of the most fundamental democratic rights that all of us have.

And if we cannot put mechanisms in place where we can ensure that all of our citizens, not just our citizens who were here pre-Katrina, and want to participate in this democratic process, if we can't do it through satellite voting in other parts of the state as well as in other parts of the country, which many of us want and has not been accepted, then I think we have a serious problem that taints the upcoming elections for mayor as well as for council members, sheriff, and everything else that's on the ballot in April.
What are the obstacles to the satellite voting centers?
Well my understanding is that the legislature recently agreed that there would be satellite voting in other parts of the state but they did not agree to outside of the state.
But not outside the state?

And we have a substantial amount of our citizens that are living in cities like Houston, Dallas, Atlanta, Memphis, and my position is, if this country can ensure that elections go forth properly in Iraq, that Iraqi citizens who are living in the United States can vote in elections here, I don't understand why we can't ensure that for tax paying citizens from the city of New Orleans.
King Milling?
In terms of leadership, what does New Orleans need?
I think Norman hit it on the head.
I have been dismayed at how much time we have spent trying to castigate individuals for their leadership position during a time of unbelievable stress.
Hopefully, whomever it may be, the person who comes in would try to put this city's future ahead of almost anything else because that's what we all want.
To be able to serve its citizens in a way that is better than it was before.
You mention Jordan and Saudi Arabia.
Did Donald Trump talk anything about who America would ally with in this fight?
I'd like to thank all of you for talking with us about the future of your city.
And also just, personally, Dr. Norman Francis, president of Xavier University and chair of the Louisiana Recovery Authority, as you've told us, your own, you were left homeless by Katrina.
Absolutely.
I have no home now.
I'm living in temporary quarters, thanks to my oldest son.
And Kim Boyle, of the mayor's Bring New Orleans Back Commission.
Thank you.
Took some pretty fair damage yourself here from Katrina.
Yes, I did.
My parents lost their home.
They're living with me now, and we're living back in my house, but it did suffer some damage.
But we're happy to be back.
And King Milling, President of Whitney National Bank, you were high and dry.
I was high and dry.
I'm so fortunate I get embarrassed to talk about it.
Well, thanks to all three of you for talking with us about New Orleans and the future.
Thank you very much.
Thank you.
NPR's senior news analyst, Daniel Schorr, sees something else at work.
This is Daniel Schorr.
An election for president is underway in Venezuela.
The autocratic Nicolas Maduro is seeking another term, despite his country's economic meltdown.
He faces accusations that the election is designed to ensure he'll win.
The mainstream opposition is boycotting the vote for that reason.
All this amid economic catastrophe there with shortages of everything and a growing refugee crisis with Venezuelans fleeing to neighboring countries.
We're joined now by NPR's Philip Reeves, who's in the capital.
Good morning.
Good morning.
What is the scene there in Caracas?
Well, shortly after polls opened, Lulu, I drove around the city.
I went through the east, where the opposition parties have a lot of support.
But as you mentioned, they're boycotting this, so it's hardly surprising.
The streets there were pretty much deserted.
But I then went to a polling station at a school in the west of Caracas, which is a stronghold of the ruling Socialist Party.
And there weren't very many people voting there.
People told me that in previous elections, the place is very busy.
It certainly wasn't today.
The U.S.
and many others say this election is not democratic.
Are you seeing evidence on the ground of that?

I mean, the government of Nicolas Maduro controls most of the media, the electoral authorities and the legislature that it actually created last year in an election that was widely seen as rigged and then called this vote.
So it has all of that.
It's also recently been providing more food handouts.
Yesterday, I went to a giant supermarket where the shelves are now stocked with lots of stuff - ham, pasta, sardines.
People said they're - that much of this food just wasn't there three weeks ago, and the prices are now significantly lower than before.
But what was fascinating was that in the supermarket's underground car park, there were more than 100 troops from the National Guard in riot gear and about the same number outside with water cannon.
So the government's clearly concerned about the risk of violence here.
When you talk to people on the streets there, what are they saying about this election when there's so much going on, when the country's in such a difficult place?
A lot of people seem absolutely uninterested in it.
They're struggling to get by and focusing on that.

I did spend some time in a public square talking to people and met a few supporters of Nicolas Maduro who seem sincerely to support him and agree with his argument that Venezuela's a victim of an economic war led by the U.S.
But his fans are hugely outnumbered by critics.
I met a man called Jose Luiz (ph), who's 40.
I asked him - and I asked him whether, you know, there's any chance whether Nicolas Maduro could lose this election.
(Speaking Spanish).
So Jose Luiz thinks Maduro would lose if the elections were clean, but he says they're clearly tainted.
He used to be a computer engineer, but he can't get work in that area.
So he's now a security guard.
It's actually Jose Luiz's birthday today, Election Day, and I asked him if he'd celebrate.
(Speaking Spanish).
And he replied that in Venezuela, there's absolutely nothing to celebrate.
He says every night, he sees about 50 people rifling for food in trash outside the building where he works, a lot of people.
And that clearly distresses him and many others here.
A lot of people here seem to have waited until the last minute, though, to decide whether to vote.
And among them is Marilyn Villalobos (ph), who's a housewife, age 54.
(Speaking Spanish).
She says she's not decided whether she'll vote.
But if she does, it won't be for Maduro.
One thing she does know, though, Lulu, is that she's going to leave the country if and when he wins.
She has a son in Colombia, and she says she's all set to join him, becoming one of the multitude who've fled Venezuela in this crisis recently.
Multitude, indeed.
As you mentioned, the mainstream opposition is boycotting this election.
But there's one significant candidate - Henri Falcon, a former state governor.
Some say he's a collaborator meant to give this election the veneer of legitimacy.
But just briefly, is he a serious challenger?
He's performed strongly in the polls, and some put him ahead in recent weeks, some of these polls.
Everyone's focused on how many votes he'll get.
It's unclear what the government would do if he actually won.
Many people here find it hard to believe that Nicolas Maduro would actually leave power if he did so, though.
That's NPR's Philip Reeves in Caracas.
Thank you so very much.
You're welcome.
One of the diplomats at the center of the impeachment inquiry is set to appear tomorrow before the House committees investigating the whistleblower complaint.
Kurt Volker was, until last week, the Trump administration's envoy to Ukraine.
His job was to promote a peace process between Russia and Ukraine, but he also found himself helping Trump's lawyer on a quest to get Ukraine to dig up dirt on Trump's rivals.
NPR's Michele Kelemen reports.
What are Democrats doing so wrong in rural America?
Unfortunately, it feeds a false narrative that all veterans have post-traumatic stress, that post-traumatic stress leads to mass shootings, that combat translates to these types of events.
And in this situation, we don't know any of those things to be true.
